purpose_built.name: Purpose-built carrier
purpose_built.description: Dedicated harvester/processor bases (e.g., TimberPro, Ponsse) working roadside or at landings.

references.citation: Magagnotti, N. et al. 2017. Use, Utilization, Productivity and Fuel Consumption of Purpose-Built and Excavator-Based Harvesters and Processors in Italy. Forests 8(485).
references.notes: Medians across three purpose-built Italian harvesters: utilisation 78 %, productivity 13.3 m³/PMH, fuel 0.70 L/m³.

references.citation: Borz, S.A. et al. 2023. Bucking at Landing by a Single-Grip Harvester. Forests 14(465).
references.notes: Tracked harvester bucking roadside piles averaged 21.41 m³/PMH, 0.78 L/m³ fuel, 95 % recovery.

notes: Delay multiplier approximates Magagnotti et al. (2017) median utilisation (78 %).
Use this profile when processors sit on purpose-built carriers or factory CTL bases.

excavator.name: Excavator-based carrier
excavator.description: Tracked excavators fitted with processing heads (shovel processors, stroke processors).
notes: Productivity regression from Nakagawa et al. (2010) landing processor study (Hokkaido excavator + single-grip head).
Utilisation and fuel ratios from Magagnotti et al. (2017): excavator carriers averaged 54 % utilisation, 1.71 L/m³ (≈2.4× purpose-built).
Bertone & Manzone (2025) observed 48 % of cycle time lost to yarder wait when a tracked excavator processor worked under a cable system in the Italian Alps.

references.citation: Nakagawa, M. et al. 2010. Effect of tree size on time of each work element and processing productivity using an excavator-based single-grip harvester or processor at a landing. J. For. Res. 15:226–233.
references.notes: Delay-free productivity (m³/PMH) = 0.363 × DBH^1.116 for excavator-based landing processor.
Medians across excavator-based units: utilisation 54 %, productivity 8.7 m³/PMH, fuel 1.71 L/m³ (≈2.4× purpose-built).

references.citation: Bertone, F. & Manzone, M. 2025. Productivity and costs of a tracked excavator-based processor at the cable yarder landing in the North-western Italian Alps. Int. J. Forest Engineering 36(1).
references.notes: Observed productivity 25.7 m³/PMH with 48 % delays due to yarder wait; shift cost ≈€103/SMH.
Use as a counterpoint: purpose-built landing harvester achieved 21.41 m³/PMH with 0.78 L/m³ fuel.
